trans-unit.source: About images for virtual machines
trans-unit.target: About images for virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Learn about how images are used with virtual machines in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn about how images are used with virtual machines in Azure.

trans-unit.source: About images for virtual machines
trans-unit.target: About images for virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Images are used in Azure to provide a new virtual machine with an operating system.
trans-unit.target: Images are used in Azure to provide a new virtual machine with an operating system.

trans-unit.source: An image might also have one or more data disks.
trans-unit.target: An image might also have one or more data disks.

trans-unit.source: Images are available from several sources:
trans-unit.target: Images are available from several sources:

trans-unit.source: Azure offers images in the <link><linkText>Marketplace</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Azure offers images in the <link><linkText>Marketplace</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You’ll find recent versions of Windows Server and distributions of the Linux operating system.
trans-unit.target: You’ll find recent versions of Windows Server and distributions of the Linux operating system.

trans-unit.source: Some images also contain applications, such as SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Some images also contain applications, such as SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: MSDN Benefit and MSDN Pay-as-You-Go subscribers have access to additional images.
trans-unit.target: MSDN Benefit and MSDN Pay-as-You-Go subscribers have access to additional images.

trans-unit.source: The open source community offers images through <link><linkText>VM Depot</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The open source community offers images through <link><linkText>VM Depot</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You also can store and use your own images in Azure, by either capturing an existing Azure virtual machine for use as an image or uploading an image.
trans-unit.target: You also can store and use your own images in Azure, by either capturing an existing Azure virtual machine for use as an image or uploading an image.

trans-unit.source: About VM images and OS images
trans-unit.target: About VM images and OS images

trans-unit.source: Two types of images can be used in Azure: VM image and OS image.
trans-unit.target: Two types of images can be used in Azure: VM image and OS image.

trans-unit.source: A VM image includes an operating system and all disks attached to a virtual machine when the image is created.
trans-unit.target: A VM image includes an operating system and all disks attached to a virtual machine when the image is created.

trans-unit.source: This is the newer type of image.
trans-unit.target: This is the newer type of image.

trans-unit.source: Before VM images were introduced, an image in Azure could have only a generalized operating system and no additional disks.
trans-unit.target: Before VM images were introduced, an image in Azure could have only a generalized operating system and no additional disks.

trans-unit.source: A VM image that contains only a generalized operating system is basically the same as the original type of image, the OS image.
trans-unit.target: A VM image that contains only a generalized operating system is basically the same as the original type of image, the OS image.

trans-unit.source: You can create your own images, based on a virtual machine in Azure, or a virtual machine running elsewhere that you copy and upload.
trans-unit.target: You can create your own images, based on a virtual machine in Azure, or a virtual machine running elsewhere that you copy and upload.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use an image to create more than one virtual machine, you’ll need to prepare it for use as an image by generalizing it.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use an image to create more than one virtual machine, you’ll need to prepare it for use as an image by generalizing it.

trans-unit.source: To create a Windows Server image, run the Sysprep command on the server to generalize it before you upload the .vhd file.
trans-unit.target: To create a Windows Server image, run the Sysprep command on the server to generalize it before you upload the .vhd file.

trans-unit.source: For details about Sysprep, see <link><linkText>How to Use Sysprep: An Introduction</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details about Sysprep, see <link><linkText>How to Use Sysprep: An Introduction</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To create a Linux image, depending on the software distribution, you’ll need to run a set of commands that are specific to the distribution, as well as run the Azure Linux Agent.
trans-unit.target: To create a Linux image, depending on the software distribution, you’ll need to run a set of commands that are specific to the distribution, as well as run the Azure Linux Agent.

trans-unit.source: Working with images
trans-unit.target: Working with images

trans-unit.source: You can use the Azure Command-Line Interface (CLI) for Mac, Linux, and Windows or Azure PowerShell module to manage the images available to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can use the Azure Command-Line Interface (CLI) for Mac, Linux, and Windows or Azure PowerShell module to manage the images available to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: You also can use the Azure portal for some image tasks, but the command line gives you more options.
trans-unit.target: You also can use the Azure portal for some image tasks, but the command line gives you more options.

trans-unit.source: For information about using these tools with Resource Manager deployments, see <link><linkText>Navigating and Selecting Azure Virtual Machine images with PowerShell and the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about using these tools with Resource Manager deployments, see <link><linkText>Navigating and Selecting Azure Virtual Machine images with PowerShell and the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For examples of using the tools in a classic deployment:
trans-unit.target: For examples of using the tools in a classic deployment:

trans-unit.source: For CLI, see "Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine images" in <link><linkText>Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Service Management</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For CLI, see "Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine images" in <link><linkText>Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Service Management</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: For Azure PowerShell, see the following list of commands.
trans-unit.target: For Azure PowerShell, see the following list of commands.

trans-unit.source: For an example of finding an image to create a VM, see "Step 3: Determine the ImageFamily" in <link><linkText>Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For an example of finding an image to create a VM, see "Step 3: Determine the ImageFamily" in <link><linkText>Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Get all images:Get-AzureVMImagereturns a list of all the images available in your current subscription: your images as well as those provided by Azure or partners.
trans-unit.target: Get all images:Get-AzureVMImagereturns a list of all the images available in your current subscription: your images as well as those provided by Azure or partners.

trans-unit.source: This means you might get a large list.
trans-unit.target: This means you might get a large list.

trans-unit.source: The next examples show how to get a shorter list.
trans-unit.target: The next examples show how to get a shorter list.

trans-unit.source: Get image families:Get-AzureVMImage | select ImageFamily gets a list of image families by showing strings ImageFamily property.
trans-unit.target: Get image families:Get-AzureVMImage | select ImageFamily gets a list of image families by showing strings ImageFamily property.

trans-unit.source: Get all images in a specific family: Get-AzureVMImage | Where-Object {$_.ImageFamily -eq $family}
trans-unit.target: Get all images in a specific family: Get-AzureVMImage | Where-Object {$_.ImageFamily -eq $family}

trans-unit.source: Find VM Images: Get-AzureVMImage | where {(gm –InputObject $_ -Name DataDiskConfigurations) -ne $null} | Select -Property Label, ImageName this works by filtering the DataDiskConfiguration property, which only applies to VM Images.
trans-unit.target: Find VM Images: Get-AzureVMImage | where {(gm –InputObject $_ -Name DataDiskConfigurations) -ne $null} | Select -Property Label, ImageName this works by filtering the DataDiskConfiguration property, which only applies to VM Images.

trans-unit.source: This example also filters the output to only the label and image name.
trans-unit.target: This example also filters the output to only the label and image name.

trans-unit.source: Save a generalized image: Save-AzureVMImage –ServiceName "myServiceName" –Name "MyVMtoCapture" –OSState "Generalized" –ImageName "MyVmImage" –ImageLabel "This is my generalized image"
trans-unit.target: Save a generalized image: Save-AzureVMImage –ServiceName "myServiceName" –Name "MyVMtoCapture" –OSState "Generalized" –ImageName "MyVmImage" –ImageLabel "This is my generalized image"

trans-unit.source: Save a specialized image: Save-AzureVMImage –ServiceName "mySvc2" –Name "MyVMToCapture2" –ImageName "myFirstVMImageSP" –OSState "Specialized" -Verbose
trans-unit.target: Save a specialized image: Save-AzureVMImage –ServiceName "mySvc2" –Name "MyVMToCapture2" –ImageName "myFirstVMImageSP" –OSState "Specialized" -Verbose

trans-unit.source: [Azure.Tip] The OSState parameter is required if you want to create a VM image, which includes data disks as well as the operating system disk.
trans-unit.target: [Azure.Tip] The OSState parameter is required if you want to create a VM image, which includes data disks as well as the operating system disk.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t use the parameter, the cmdlet creates an OS image.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t use the parameter, the cmdlet creates an OS image.

trans-unit.source: The value of the parameter indicates whether the image is generalized or specialized, based on whether the operating system disk has been prepared for reuse.
trans-unit.target: The value of the parameter indicates whether the image is generalized or specialized, based on whether the operating system disk has been prepared for reuse.

trans-unit.source: Delete an image: Remove-AzureVMImage –ImageName "MyOldVmImage"
trans-unit.target: Delete an image: Remove-AzureVMImage –ImageName "MyOldVmImage"

trans-unit.target: Additional resources
